articles.headline: In Baghdad Ruins, Remains of a Cultural Bridge
articles.snippet: A bombing in April also destroyed the former home of a cosmopolitan writer and artist, Jabra Ibrahim Jabra.
articles.abstract: A bombing in April also destroyed the former home of a cosmopolitan writer and artist, Jabra Ibrahim Jabra.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Report No. 25, dated April 4 and written by Col. Qais Hussein, was clinical, the anonymous survey of an explosion in a city where explosions are ordinary.

articles.headline: U.S. Approves Google’s Deal for AdMob
articles.snippet: The surprising endorsement by the Federal Trade Commission of Google’s deal for AdMob follows Apple’s purchase of Quattro Wireless, an AdMob rival.
articles.abstract: The surprising endorsement by the Federal Trade Commission of Google’s deal for AdMob follows Apple’s purchase of Quattro Wireless, an AdMob rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After an intensive six-month review, Google won approval from the Federal Trade Commission on Friday for its $750 million acquisition of the mobile advertising company AdMob.

articles.headline: Detainees Barred From Access to U.S. Courts
articles.snippet: It is not clear how a ruling that found that detainees in Afghanistan have no right to challenge their imprisonment in U.S. courts may affect detention policies.
articles.abstract: It is not clear how a ruling that found that detainees in Afghanistan have no right to challenge their imprisonment in U.S. courts may affect detention policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruled Friday that three men who had been detained by the United States military for years without trial in Afghanistan had no recourse to American courts. The decision was a broad victory for the Obama administration in its efforts to hold terrorism suspects overseas for indefinite periods without judicial oversight.

articles.headline: Pakistani Major Among 2 New Arrests in Bombing
articles.snippet: A Pakistani officer’s connection to a failed bombing in Times Square did not signal Pakistani Army involvement.
articles.abstract: A Pakistani officer’s connection to a failed bombing in Times Square did not signal Pakistani Army involvement.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An army officer and a businessman have been detained as part of a widening inquiry into a circle of Pakistanis who had some knowledge of the activities of the man charged with trying to set off a crude car bomb in Times Square, according to a Western official and an American intelligence official.

articles.headline: Arizona Law Reveals Split Within G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Republicans are divided over illegal immigration, and the fault lines in the states are anything but predictable.
articles.abstract: Republicans are divided over illegal immigration, and the fault lines in the states are anything but predictable.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Republican lawmakers and candidates are increasingly divided over illegal immigration — torn between the need to attract Latino support, especially at the ballot box, and rallying party members who support tougher action.

articles.headline: Reconciliation for 2 Financial Overhaul Bills
articles.snippet: Differences in the two versions of new regulations for Wall Street passed in Congress have to be settled, and that could bring changes to the final version.
articles.abstract: Differences in the two versions of new regulations for Wall Street passed in Congress have to be settled, and that could bring changes to the final version.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh off Senate approval of the overhaul of the nation’s financial regulations, the Obama administration quickly moved on Friday to shape the final version of the bill.

articles.headline: A Progressive Agenda to Remake Washington
articles.snippet: The financial reform bill completes a period of legislative and executive activity that rivals any other since the New Deal in scope and ambition.
articles.abstract: The financial reform bill completes a period of legislative and executive activity that rivals any other since the New Deal in scope and ambition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

articles.headline: ‘Lost’ Fans Suffer From Blabbermouths Online
articles.snippet: For the finale, ABC is taking steps to keep online chatter from ruining the suspense across the time zones.
articles.abstract: For the finale, ABC is taking steps to keep online chatter from ruining the suspense across the time zones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Erin Farley has her plans for Sunday all laid out. Two hours before the last episode of “Lost” is broadcast three time zones away, she will shut down her home Internet connection. TweetDeck? Off. Facebook? Off. Her cellphone? Stashed out of reach.

articles.headline: Just Weather, Thanks, Dish Tells Channel
articles.snippet: When the Dish Network threatened to drop the Weather Channel this week, it cited too much “weather-tainment.” An even bigger reason appears to be cost.
articles.abstract: When the Dish Network threatened to drop the Weather Channel this week, it cited too much “weather-tainment.” An even bigger reason appears to be cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: The woes of the Weather Channel can be summed up in one movie title:  “Misery.”

articles.headline: Deal Puts Yellowstone Bison on Ted Turner’s Range
articles.snippet: A lawsuit opposing an agreement letting Mr. Turner keep bison on his ranch argues that they belong to the public.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit opposing an agreement letting Mr. Turner keep bison on his ranch argues that they belong to the public.

articles.headline: Europeans Fear Crisis Threatens Liberal Benefits
articles.snippet: The deficit crisis that threatens the euro — along with an aging population and low growth — has undermined the sustainability of Europe’s standard of social welfare.
articles.abstract: The deficit crisis that threatens the euro — along with an aging population and low growth — has undermined the sustainability of Europe’s standard of social welfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Across Western Europe, the “lifestyle superpower,” the assumptions and gains of a lifetime are suddenly in doubt. The deficit crisis that threatens the euro has also undermined the sustainability of the European standard of social welfare, built by left-leaning governments since the end of World War II.

articles.headline: Sure, It’s Big. But Is That Bad?
articles.snippet: The government is looking for signs that Google’s enormous market power may be hurting competition in Web search and advertising.
articles.abstract: The government is looking for signs that Google’s enormous market power may be hurting competition in Web search and advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the 1990s, Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer, almost single-handedly brought the antitrust weight of the federal government down on that era’s high-tech heavyweight, Microsoft. Now Mr. Reback contends there is a dangerous new monopolist in the catbird seat: the search giant Google.

articles.headline: Suddenly, the Rating Agencies Don’t Look Untouchable
articles.snippet: The big rating agencies find themselves at an unusually vulnerable moment, facing lawsuits as well as assaults on their power by Congress and regulators.
articles.abstract: The big rating agencies find themselves at an unusually vulnerable moment, facing lawsuits as well as assaults on their power by Congress and regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: RON GRASSI will admit that when he decided to sue the three major rating agencies in early 2009, he was too enraged to think about his odds. A retired family law specialist who lives in California, he filed his suit in a low boil a few months after $40,000 in Lehman Brothers corporate bonds he owned all but vanished when the investment bank collapsed.

articles.headline: ‘100% Protected’ Isn’t as Safe as It Sounds
articles.snippet: A lawyer representing investors said the risks of principal protected notes were not “honestly disclosed.”
articles.abstract: A lawyer representing investors said the risks of principal protected notes were not “honestly disclosed.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BROKERS selling complex securities that they once contended were safe and sound have saddled individual investors with billions in losses since the credit bubble burst. Remember auction-rate securities? Those were peddled to investors as just as good as cash — until they no longer were after that market seized up in 2008.

articles.headline: Financial Overhaul Bill Poses Big Test for Lobbyists
articles.snippet: The House Financial Services Committee has been a magnet for money from Wall Street, but the sweeping new regulations approved by the Senate are trying that relationship.
articles.abstract: The House Financial Services Committee has been a magnet for money from Wall Street, but the sweeping new regulations approved by the Senate are trying that relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last Wednesday, Representative David Scott, Democrat of Georgia, mingled with insurance and financial executives and other supporters at a lunchtime fund-raiser in his honor at a chic Washington wine bar before rushing out to cast a House vote.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: Escape Attempt Led to Killings of Unarmed Inmates
articles.snippet: After the January earthquake, when the Haitian police stormed a prison, they fatally shot at least 12 detainees, a New York Times investigation found.
articles.abstract: After the January earthquake, when the Haitian police stormed a prison, they fatally shot at least 12 detainees, a New York Times investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: LES CAYES, Haiti — When the earth shook violently on Jan. 12, the inmates in this southern city’s squalid prison clamored to be released, screaming: “Help! We’re going to die in here.”
articles.byline: By Deborah Sontag and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: Republicans See Big Chance, but Are Worried, Too
articles.snippet: Republicans believe they will do well in the midterm elections, but are debating how to take on the Democrats.
articles.abstract: Republicans believe they will do well in the midterm elections, but are debating how to take on the Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans remain confident of making big gains in the fall elections, but as the midterm campaign begins in earnest, they face a series of challenges that could keep the party from fully capitalizing on an electorate clamoring for change in Washington.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Idea Man of LimeWire at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: Mark Gorton, hedge fund manager and philanthropist, says he wanted to build a subscription service working with music companies. They say he is a criminal.
articles.abstract: Mark Gorton, hedge fund manager and philanthropist, says he wanted to build a subscription service working with music companies. They say he is a criminal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Gorton is a confident guy. He’s confident about his ideas. He’s confident about his enthusiasms. And he’s confident that his successes — like making money on Wall Street and promoting alternative transportation in New York — provide a record that backs him up.

articles.headline: Rivals Seize on Troubles of Facebook
articles.snippet: For small start-up networks, privacy is a selling point as Facebook users are becoming fed up with the site’s efforts to broadcast personal information.
articles.abstract: For small start-up networks, privacy is a selling point as Facebook users are becoming fed up with the site’s efforts to broadcast personal information.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a kamikaze mission: an upstart with a meager number of users and no capital squaring off against Facebook, a social networking juggernaut with more than 400 million members and a $15 billion valuation.

articles.headline: Online News Fights to Live on Its Merits
articles.snippet: Generous donations from the Knight Foundation have helped the news site MinnPost.com to get its bearings. Now it is trying to achieve business viability.
articles.abstract: Generous donations from the Knight Foundation have helped the news site MinnPost.com to get its bearings. Now it is trying to achieve business viability.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s telling that one of the more promising experiments in the next version of regional news is located in an industrial park near the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. The backdrop seems fitting.

articles.headline: When the President Travels, It’s Cheaper for Reporters to Stay Home
articles.snippet: Press flights have been sharply curtailed in recent months, a victim of cost-cutting by news organizations that are struggling to stay profitable.
articles.abstract: Press flights have been sharply curtailed in recent months, a victim of cost-cutting by news organizations that are struggling to stay profitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The news media have found a new area of coverage ripe for cost-cutting: the president of the United States.

articles.headline: As Reform Takes Shape, Some Relief on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Bankers and analysts think the Senate bill will reduce industry profits but leave its size and power mostly intact.
articles.abstract: Bankers and analysts think the Senate bill will reduce industry profits but leave its size and power mostly intact.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial reform legislation making its way through Congress has Wall Street executives privately relieved that the bill does not do more to fundamentally change how the industry does business.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Rules Grow, Banks Stay Same Size
articles.snippet: The approach embraced by President Obama reflected the judgments that the financial system was sound, and that the problem was a lack of government.
articles.abstract: The approach embraced by President Obama reflected the judgments that the financial system was sound, and that the problem was a lack of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Broadly speaking, there were two ways for the federal government to respond to the financial crisis: supersize regulation or downsize the financial industry.

articles.headline: U.S. Tries to Reintegrate Taliban Soldiers
articles.snippet: Even as officials debate how to reconcile with members of the Taliban, military commanders on the ground in Afghanistan are proceeding on their own.
articles.abstract: Even as officials debate how to reconcile with members of the Taliban, military commanders on the ground in Afghanistan are proceeding on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAN POSHTEH, Afghanistan — The young Taliban prisoner was led blindfolded to a sweltering military tent, seated among 17 village elders and then, eyes uncovered, faced a chief accuser brandishing a document with the elders’ signatures or thumbprints.

articles.headline: Cuts to Child Care Subsidy Thwart More Job Seekers
articles.snippet: State cuts in child care are forcing many low-income parents to forgo work, and threaten to undo the progress of welfare changes enacted in 1996.
articles.abstract: State cuts in child care are forcing many low-income parents to forgo work, and threaten to undo the progress of welfare changes enacted in 1996.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Able-bodied, outgoing and accustomed to working, Alexandria Wallace wants to earn a paycheck. But that requires someone to look after her 3-year-old daughter, and Ms. Wallace, a 22-year-old single mother, cannot afford child care.

articles.headline: Despite Moratorium, Drilling Projects Move Ahead
articles.snippet: At least five environmental waivers have been granted since President Obama announced a moratorium.
articles.abstract: At least five environmental waivers have been granted since President Obama announced a moratorium.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days since President Obama announced a moratorium on permits for drilling new offshore oil wells and a halt to a controversial type of environmental waiver that was given to the Deepwater Horizon rig, at least seven new permits for various types of drilling and five environmental waivers have been granted, according to records.

articles.headline: Korean Tensions Grow as South Curbs Trade to North
articles.snippet: Moves by President Lee Myung-bak amounted to the most serious actions the South could take short of an armed retaliation for what Mr. Lee called the deliberate sinking of a South Korean warship.
articles.abstract: Moves by President Lee Myung-bak amounted to the most serious actions the South could take short of an armed retaliation for what Mr. Lee called the deliberate sinking of a South Korean warship.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Tensions escalated sharply Monday on the Korean peninsula, as South Korean President Lee Myung-bak said that his nation would cut nearly all trade with North Korea, deny North Korean merchant ships use of South Korean sea lanes and ask the United Nations Security Council to punish the North for what he called the deliberate sinking of a South Korean warship two months ago.
